Class LineSegment

  • java.lang.Object
    • LineSegment

  • public class LineSegment
extends java.lang.Object
    This class represents a Line Segment defined by two outermost points, one point a (let's say it's the start point) and another, point b (we can consider it the end point).
    Since:
    20/10/2016
    Version:
    2.0
    Author:
    Andre Pedro, Ricardo Reais, Vasco Carvalho
    See Also:
    Point

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      private Point a
      The outermost Point a can be considered the start and b the end point, both points connected form the line segment.
      private Point b
      The outermost Point a can be considered the start and b the end point, both points connected form the line segment.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      LineSegment(Point a, Point b)
      The creation of a valid LineSegment implies that the start and end points must be different, or else we would only have one simple point.

      double distanceTo(Point p)
      We can calculate the distance of a point to a line if the point is located between the line segment outermost points, this is, it's x coordinate is bigger than the smallest x coordinate of the segment and it is also smaller than the largest x coordinate of the segment.

        public Point midPoint()
        This mid point is obtained using the formula: Center = ((x1+x2)/2, (y1+y2)/2).

        See Also:

        public boolean isDiagonal()
        Checks if the line segment is not horizontal and is not vertical simultaneously.
        Returns:
        True if the line segment is diagonal, else false.

        Returns:
        Line Segment length. (Distance between starting and end points)
        See Also:
        Point.distanceTo(Point)

      • slope

        public double slope()
        Returns:
        Line Segment slope. If the segment is vertical the value is infinity, by convenience it returns the maximum double value instead of infinity.

      • intercept

        public double intercept()
        The intercept of a line segment is the y value of the point where it's line crosses the y axis.
        Returns:
        Line Segment intercept.

      • distanceTo

        public double distanceTo(Point p)
        We can calculate the distance of a point to a line if the point is located between the line segment outermost points, this is, it's x coordinate is bigger than the smallest x coordinate of the segment and it is also smaller than the largest x coordinate of the segment. Else, we calculate the minimum distance between the point and the outermost points of the segment.
        Parameters:
        p - Point to calculate the distance between.
        Returns:
        Line Segment distance to a point.
        See Also:
        Point.distanceTo(LineSegment)

      • intersects

        public boolean intersects(LineSegment ls)
        The algorithm used is a modified version of the algorithm to check the intersection between two line segments, as described on: http://moderntone.blogspot.pt/2013/02/a-simple-algorithm-to-determine-whether.html By: Tom. The modification is: When both segments are diagonal, the x value needs to be between the maximum of the lowest x values, and the minimum of the largest x values of the segments. Instead of: X needs to be between x1 and x2, as seen on the original algorithm Another detail added is, when the segments are collinear, they don't intersect. Which differs from the original algorithm.
        Parameters:
        ls - Line segment to check the intersection.
        Returns:
        True if the segments intersect, else false.
        See Also:
        slope(), intercept(), isVertical(), getSmallestX(), getLargestX(), Point

        Returns a string representation of the object. In general, the toString method returns a string that "textually represents" this object.
